Twelver

This Shiite character is part of the Imami or Twelver sect that recognizes twelve imams. They are more literalistic and legalistic compared to some Shiite sects in matters of theology, focusing on divine law (shari'ah) and the deeds and sayings (sunnah) of Muhammad and his successors (the Ahlu l-Bayt), who as A'immah were guides and a light to God.
Ismaili

This Shiite character is part of the Ismaili or Sevener sect that recognizes seven imams. They focus on the mystical path and nature of God and the divine manifestation in the personage of the "Imam of the Time" as the "Face of God".
Zaydi

This Shiite character is part of the Zaydi or Fiver sect that recognizes five imams. Compared to other Shiite branches, the Zaydi bear many similarities with the Sunni, and are known to be more tolerant and moderate. They are also theologically close, though not exactly similar, to the rationalist Mu'tazili school of Sunni Islam.
I am no longer a Shiite, so why should I care about how many imams there are?

The Dharma - that is, the teachings of the Buddha - have spread once more across the Silk Road, and now dominates much of Central Asia like it did in the days of old. Word of this has even spread all the way to China. With this in mind, the monks of Shaolin Temple, famous for its traditions of martial arts - taught by the revered Buddhist master Bodhidharma - have decided to establish a branch in the West, in order to protect the Buddhists of Central Asia.\n\nThe Western Shaolin Monastery, as it shall be known, will strive to uphold justice and order in these turbulent times. Adventurous and noble monks have traveled afar to settle in the West so that the Dharma may spread and flourish.

Hindu beliefs have penetrated deep into the heartlands of western Asia, and many have converted to this Indian creed. However, a number of Hindus realize that their situation is precarious, for they are surrounded by religious enemies who label them as idolators and irrational polytheists. As such, a group of Hindu veterans have decided to form a holy order called the Warriors of Shiva.\n\nThese Warriors of Shiva hope to protect Hindus from attacks by zealous, bloodthirsty Muslims, Christians, and any others who antagonize the Hindu gods. Though some Hindus argue that these Warriors of Shiva are betraying their own beliefs, the new order sees no contradiction, and will protect their faith to the last man.

The Ibadi sect of Islam has always been under threat from the more powerful Sunnis and Shiites. Because of this, the Ibadi had to find refuge in defensible locations, such as the harsh mountains of the Maghreb. Here, a Berber tribe, known as the Mozabites, adopted the Ibadi creed and follow it devoutly - they have continuously repelled incursions from their Sunni and Shiite neighbors.\n\nThe fame and prestige of the Mozabite has swelled to the point where they are now considered the defenders of Ibadi Islam. As the Mozabite tribe grows in power and size, some of them have banded to form a trans-regional holy order! With the Ibadi sect spreading across the world, it may face threats not only from Sunni and Shiite rulers, but those of other faiths as well, so the rise of the Mozabites could not have come at a more opportune time for the Ibadi faithful.
